issues.description: The problem statement UML declares Stock.take(String) to return an int (used as a sentinel -1 when unavailable), and the provided solution implements Stock.take(String) to return an int. However, the template repository's Stock.take(String) method returns a boolean. This return-type mismatch is structural: students implementing SealSaloon (which, per the specification, should call stock.take(...) and check for -1) will be unable to follow the intended design using the template API. This prevents straightforward implementation of the checkOrderReady logic and will cause confusion or compilation errors if students follow the problem/solution expectations.
issues.suggested_fix: Change the template's Stock.take(String) method signature and implementation to return an int (matching the UML and the solution). Implement it to return -1 when the ingredient does not exist or quantity < 1, otherwise decrement the quantity and return the new quantity. This aligns the template API with the problem specification and the reference solution, allowing students to implement checkOrderReady() as intended.
